Graphical abstract This review summarizes the current progress on single-atom catalysts (SACs) for high-energy metal-sulfur batteries from aspects of synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical performance. Challenges and future perspectives are discussed for designing high-performance SACs. Metal-sulfur batteries are recognized as a promising candidate for next generation electrochemical energy storage systems owing to their high theoretical energy density, low cost and environmental friendliness. However, sluggish redox kinetics of sulfur species and the shuttle effect lead to large polarization and severe capacity decay. Numerous approaches from physical barrier, chemical adsorption strategies to electrocatalysts have been tried to solve these issues and pushed the rate and cycle performance of sulfur electrodes to higher levels. Most recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) with high catalytic efficiency have been introduced into metal-sulfur systems to achieve fast redox kinetics of sulfur conversion. In this review, we systematically summarize the current progress on SACs for sulfur electrodes from aspects of synthesis, characterization and electrochemical performance. Challenges and potential solutions for designing SACs for high-performance sulfur electrodes are discussed. Keywords Single-atom catalysts Metal-sulfur batteries Redox kinetics Synthesis Characterization Electrochemical performance 1 Introduction Efficient energy storage represents one of the most attractive topics in this power-demanding world [1,2]. With the rapid demand growth of electrochemical energy storage devices, conventional lithium-ion batteries are gradually unable to meet the requirements because of its relatively low energy density (<400 Wh kg−1) and high cost [3–5]. Developing a new generation of batteries with high specific energy, low cost and high security for commercialization is imminent. A large number of state-of-the-art secondary battery systems have attracted our attention, such as alkali metal (Li/Na/K)-chalcogen (S/O2) batteries and novel lithium batteries relied on advanced electrode materials. Among them, metal-sulfur batteries are recognized as promising candidates for next-generation electrochemical energy storage systems owing to the low-cost and environment-friendly sulfur with high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh/g) [6,7]. Metal-sulfur batteries family includes lithium-sulfur (Li-S), sodium-sulfur (Na-S), potassium-sulfur (K-S), magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S), calcium-sulfur (Ca-S), and aluminum-sulfur (Al-S) batteries. In Li-S batteries, sulfur delivers an average voltage of 2.15 V (vs. Li/Li+) as cathode. Accordingly, when assembled with a lithium metal anode (3860 mAh/g), the Li-S batteries possess a high theoretical specific energy of 2600 Wh kg−1 [8,9]. For high-temperature Na-S battery operated at 300–350 °C, severe safety concerns are suffered, and the incomplete reduction of sulfur and the maintenance of high operating temperature reduce the actual energy density [10], while room-temperature Na-S batteries have captured the attention for better safety, higher energy density (1276 Wh kg−1) and lower operation cost [11]. Compared with Li-S and Na-S batteries, research of other metal-sulfur started relative late, and the electrochemical mechanism has not been fully clear. However, from the perspectives of elemental abundance, material cost, theoretical capacity, and operational safety, metals K, Mg, Ca, Al are also promoting candidates as the anode of high energy metal-sulfur batteries [12]. As metal-sulfur batteries have the same sulfur cathode, they have a similar reaction mechanism that solid sulfur (cyclo-octasulfur S8 in most cases) needs to experience a multi-step electrochemical reduction process to form soluble polysulfide intermediates and generate solid sulfides at the end of discharge. Take a typical Li-S battery as an example to introduce the electrochemical process of sulfur electrodes, and its operation (charge and discharge) is shown in Fig. 1 . Because sulfur is in the charged state, the operation starts with discharge. During discharge, lithium metal is oxidized at the anode to produce lithium ions and electrons. The lithium ions move to the sulfur cathode through the electrolyte while the electrons travel to the sulfur cathode through the external circuit, and thereby an electrical current is generated. Sulfur reacts with lithum ions by two-electron electrochemical reduction process to form lithium polysulfides (LiPS) intermediates and generate lithium sulfide (Li2S) at the end of discharge. The discharge curve of sulfur electrodes generally consists of two discharge platforms. The first plateau at approximately 2.4 V corresponds to the solid–liquid conversion from cyclo-S8 to soluble long-chain lithium polysulfides (Li2S x , 6 ≤ x<8) (Step I). The next slope corresponds to the liquid–liquid conversion from long-chain LiPS to short-chain LiPS (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x<6) (Step Ⅱ). The second plateau at approximately 2.1 V corresponds to the liquid–solid conversion from short-chain LiPS to solid Li2S2 (Step III), and the solid–solid conversion from Li2S2 to solid Li2S (Step IV). The theoretical specific capacity of this lower voltage plateau is 1254 mAh/g, which is three times of the higher voltage plateau. The charging process appears as the reverse reaction of the discharging process, corresponding to the oxidation reaction of Li2S → Li2S2 → LiPS → S8. During the above electrochemical process, S8 and Li2S2/Li2S species with poor intrinsic electrical conductivity generally exhibit incomplete conversion [13]. In the case of different densities of α-S8 (2.07 g cm−3) and Li2S (1.66 g cm−3), the sulfur electrode has noticeable expansion of about 79% upon Li uptake, which leads to looseness and pulverize of cathode materials [14]. The intermediate LiPS are highly dissolved in electrolytes. Concentration gradient and electric field make soluble LiPS shuttle back and forth between cathode and anode during cycling and result in rapid capacity fading and low Coulombic efficiency [15–17]. In addition, because of the weak interaction with conductive matrix, LiPS suffer sluggish redox kinetics and accumulate in the electrolyte making shuttle effect severer. As shown in Fig. 1, the sluggish conversion from short-chain LiPS to Li2S2 accompanies with a potential dip, which is originated from the concentration polarization and large energy barrier for crystallization of insulating Li2S2. Due to the lack of nucleation sites, the discharging product Li2S2/Li2S tend to nonuniformly deposit on conductive skeletons. At the beginning of charging process, agglomerated Li2S2/Li2S particles are difficult to activate, and cause a large potential hill [18]. Such sluggish redox reactions generally lead to large overpotential, low sulfur utilization and practical energy density [15,19,20]. In the above electrochemical process, the sluggish kinetics of sulfur species and shuttle of polysulfides are the main reasons for low reversible capacity and rapid capacity fade. Carbon materials used as a host have been demonstrated to be a simple approach to partially solve these problems [21–24]. In 2009, Nazar and co-workers reported significantly improved performances of Li-S batteries using mesoporous carbon [25]. The combination of sulfur with porous carbon enabled the electron transfer and physical confinement of soluble LiPS. Various carbon materials, including 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and carbon nanofibers (CNFs) [26,27], 2D graphene and carbon nanosheets [28–30], and porous carbon [31,32], have been used. These carbon materials can impede the shuttle of polysulfides by physical barrier effect and provide an efficient conductive skeleton for fast electron/ion transfer. However, owing to the weak van der Waals interactions between polar LiPS and nonpolar carbon surface, LiPS may easily loss the conductive contact with the carbon substrate. The shuttle effect of LiPS cannot be suppressed during long-term cycling, and even worse as the sulfur content continuously increases [33–35]. Unmodified carbon materials have limited effects on improving the kinetics of polysulfides. To solve this problem, the adsorption strategy has been used. Various functional groups (hydroxy, carboxyl, epoxy) [30,36,37] and doped heteroatoms (N, P, O, S, and B) [38–41] in carbon materials have been proved to increase the affinity to LiPS. These functional groups and heteroatoms can effectively reduce the detachment of LiPS from conductive skeletons, enhance the redox kinetics, and achieve better cycle performance. The electrochemical process of soluble LiPS on a conductive substrate includes “adsorption” and “conversion” process [42]. Finding a medium for LiPS that can promote both processes is a promising strategy to enhance the redox kinetics. Recently, there have been unprecedented research activities on developing electrocatalysts to promote the electrochemical reaction of Li-S batteries [43,44]. These electrocatalysts mainly includes transition metals [45–48], transition metal compounds (oxides [49–54], sulfides [55–58], nitrides [59–63], phosphide [64] and carbide [65]), metal-free materials [66–68] and heterostructures [69–72], etc. These catalysts are usually at a nanometer scale, which not only exhibit strong chemisorption to LiPS, but possess a large number of catalytic sites. The conversion of LiPS adsorbed on these catalytic sites is significantly promoted due to the greatly reduced energy barriers. In particular, for discharging process, the soluble LiPS are quickly adsorbed onto catalyst surface, and further reduced to Li2S rather than shuttling. The potential dip in Fig. 1 can be effectively reduced and lead to a higher discharging voltage platform. Discharging product of Li2S can uniformly deposit on the catalyst surface. For charging process, the oxidation reaction of Li2S to Li2S2 and further to soluble LiPS can be fastened with reduced overpotential [46,73,74]. The enhanced redox kinetics of the electrochemical reaction obviously reduce the polarization and obtain higher energy efficiency and rate capability [61,75,76]. These catalysts are not only applied in the sulfur host, but also in electrolytes and separators as catalytic redox agents [73,77,78]. Since the reaction mechanism of Na-S and Li-S batteries is similar, the electrocatalysts have also been applied to Na-S batteries [79–82]. The particle size of catalysts is an important parameter to affect their performances [83]. As the adsorption and conversion only take place on the surface of nanoscale catalysts, the catalytic activity is mostly dominated by the surface atoms exposed to electrolytes with minimal contributions from the inner core. However, the surface/total atom ratio is low in a nanoparticle (about 10% for particle with a 20 nm diameter), and results in poor utilization. Most electrocatalysts are inactive, and these catalytic particles with high a weight density would undoubtedly decrease the gravimetric energy density. The long-term stability of nanoscale catalysts is also not sufficient as the aggregation cannot be avoided [83,84]. Research has shown that shrinking of the nanoparticle size down to a sub-nanometer scale can lead to an increasing number of under-coordinated metal atoms served as catalytic active sites, which reaches the maximum at the single atom level [85–87]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) with theoretical 100% atomic utilization can not only provide abundant active sites, but reduce the inactive substance fraction. The SAC-substrate interactions originated from the chemical bonding effect between single metal atoms and substrates will be maximized as well [88]. The SAC-substrate interactions have been recognized to play an important role in accelerating charge transfer between catalysts and substrates, manipulating the electronic structure of SACs, changing reaction pathways, and eventually enhancing the catalytic performance [85,89]. For practical application, gas-phase reactions have been examined on SACs, where CO oxidation and selective hydrogenation have been most widely reported [90,91]. Very recently, using SACs to catalyze electrochemical reactions in solar cells, fuel cells, secondary batteries, and electrolyzers have emerged. SACs have shown the high activity and selectivity for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) and formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) [92–95]. For metal-sulfur batteries, the sluggish reaction kinetics of sulfur cathode is urgent to be solved. Therefore, SACs began to be introduced into metal-sulfur batteries to obtain more significant catalytic performance than nanoscale catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the roadmap of catalysts for the sulfur electrode and SACs with the highest catalytic efficiency can help to achieve ultra-fast redox reaction and improve the electrochemical performance of the sulfur electrode. Although SACs used for metal-sulfur batteries have attracted tremendous attentions over the past three years, there is no comprehensive summary hitherto. A timely and systematic review is expected to further accelerate the development of emerging SACs and promote their application in high-energy metal-sulfur batteries. In this review, the catalytic mechanism of SACs for sulfur electrodes is first illustrated. The synthesis methods, characterization techniques, and the improved electrochemical performance by SACs are then introduced. The challenges and potential solutions for designing SACs for high-performance sulfur electrodes are finally discussed to highlight the future development of this field. 2 Catalytic mechanism of SACs for sulfur electrodes Study has shown that nanoscale catalysts can significantly reduce the energy barrier of sulfur conversion [57]. However, the heterogeneity and complexity of catalyst particles make the mechanism study difficult to approach the actual situation. SACs with homogeneously isolated active sites are a good choice as the model catalyst to understand the catalytic mechanism. Typical SAC@carbon materials consist of atomically dispersed transition metal centers and neighboring coordinated atoms (typically N, O or S) confined within the carbon skeleton. These coordinated atoms with lone pairs of electrons have strong coordination capability with the central metal atom to form a stable active site [96]. The catalytic mechanism of SACs for the sulfur electrode can be described as follows (Fig. 3 ): For discharging process, SAC first binds with Li2S8 by chemical adsorption. A single metal atom (SA-M) can only coordinate with one or very few LiPS molecule at a time. Through the strong “substrate-SAC-LiPS” interaction, the energy barriers for the multi-step reduction can be greatly lowered. Li2S8 is rapidly reduced to Li2S, the LiPS diffusion is thereby suppressed, and the final product of Li2S uniformly deposits on the substrate. For charging process, Li2S is adsorbed on SAC by strong bonding interaction, and further experiences an accelerated multi-step oxidation process with a lowered oxidation barrier. The enhanced oxidation kinetics of insulating Li2S/Li2S2 greatly decrease the polarization and increase the utilization of active materials. Then the charging product of S8 is be detached from SAC and redistributes on the conductive substrate. Theoretical calculation is effective to understand the above energy-related catalytic process. The local coordination structure of the reactant on SACs is calculated first, and then the binding energy, electron state, conversion energy barrier and other information are obtained. Cui et al. calculated the binding strength between Li2S6 and various SAC@nitrogen-doped graphene (SAC@NG) substrates [97]. It was found that unmodified graphene has the weakest chemical binding energy to Li2S6, while all of the SAC@NG substrates increase the binding strength by metal-S and/or N-Li bonds (Fig. 4 a). The strong SAC-LiPS interactions can effectively suppress the dissolution of LiPS in electrolyte and reduce the conversion barrier. And the decomposition barrier of Li2S on various substrates was obtained. Li2S on unmodified graphene possesses the largest decomposition barrier, much larger than on other SAC@NG substrates (Fig. 4b). When SACs coordinate with Li2S, the bond length and bond angle of Li-S bond will increase, which is beneficial to Li2S decomposition (Fig. 4c). According to the charge density difference analysis, when LiPS/Li2S adsorption happens, the electron migration mainly accumulates between the Li atoms and substrates for NG materials. While in addition to the electron transfer between Li atoms and substrates, there are also more electron transfer between S atoms and single metal atoms, thereby decreases the decomposition barriers of LiPS/Li2S [98]. Compared with only adsorption effect by heteroatoms (O and N, etc.) doping, SACs provide both adsorption and catalytic effect to aggressively promote the redox reaction. By forming robust interactions between polysulfides/sulfides and single metal atoms, and forming local coordination structure that easier for reactants decomposition, the energy barriers of conversion reactions are significantly reduced. Similar with other research, these catalytic effects of SACs can be experimentally confirmed [97]. 3 Recent progress of SACs for sulfur electrodes 3.1 Synthesis of SACs As discussed above, single metal atoms are important component of SACs to play a catalytic role. Considering the shortcomings of high cost, limited durability, and natural scarcity of precious metal catalysts, non-precious transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn, are promising catalyst candidates in sulfur electrodes. As substrates of SACs, carbon materials are rational choices because of their easily-accessible, environment-friendly feature, and wide use in sulfur electrodes. Compared to metal compound substrates, carbon materials with large specific surface areas, rich heteroatoms (O and N, etc.), and porous structure can carry and anchor a large amount of metal atoms [99]. Therefore, controllable synthesis of SAC@carbon materials for catalytic applications in sulfur electrodes will be introduced in this section. Pyrolysis method is most widely used to prepare SAC@carbon materials because of its good scalability and feasibility, and can be divided into “down-top” and “top-down” synthesis routes. In the “down-top” route, mononuclear metal complexes such as metal–organic frameworks, metal phthalocyanine complexes, and chlorides hydrateprecursors are often selected as the precursors of SACs. The mononuclear metal complexes are dispersed on the carbon substrate, and then pyrolysis, to make the ligands of mononuclear metal complexes removed and form single metal atoms on the carbon surface. In the “top-down” route, metal nanoparticles or bulk metal are starting precursors. During pyrolysis, the metal–metal bonds of metal nanoparticles or bulk metal were broken to release dispersed metal atoms and establish a new bond with the anchoring sites of the carbon surface [96,100]. The surface free energy of metal greatly increases when it is divided into isolated single atoms, such that single atoms are often susceptible to aggregation during preparation and electrochemical processes [101]. To prevent this, two strategies are often used during preparation to disperse and stabilize single metal atoms on carbon substrates, including spatial confinement strategy and coordination design strategy. For spatial confinement strategy, the atomic dispersion of SACs on carbon substrates is achieved by utilizing nanoscale pores and specific molecular diameters (e.g. chelation, and molecular tailoring of precursors) [99]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are proper substrates to stabilize SACs. On one hand, abundant metal nodes and versatile ligands of MOFs make MOFs-derived carbon with great potential served as the substrates. Huang et al. proposed a SA-Co@nitrogen-doped carbon coating layer to promote sulfur redox kinetics [102], which was prepared by one-pot synthesis of cobalt-coordinated framework porphyrin on graphene, followed by pyrolysis. Co ions were uniformly distributed in the porphyrin framework, which effectively prevented restacking in the pyrolysis process. On the other hand, the regular porous architecture of MOFs can spatially separate and encapsulate other mononuclear metal precursors. Abundant coordination sites generated after pyrolysis can serve as the anchoring sites for SACs. Micro/mesoporous carbon is another choice to stabilize SACs by spatial confinement. With a dispersed pore distribution, micro/mesoporous carbon can effectively confine and disperse metal precursor molecules in its pores. Lee et al. used a “down-top” strategy to synthesize spherical mesoporous carbon decorated by FeNC catalysts as the sulfur host for Li-S batteries (Fig. 5 a) [103]. Mononuclear metal complexes Fe(II) phthalocyanine were incorporated into the pores of mesoporous carbon spheres by impregnation. After pyrolysis under Ar/NH3 atmosphere, SA-Fe@spherical mesoporous carbon with uniform FeNC catalytic sites was prepared. As discussed in Section 2, the N, O, S and other nonmetal atoms with lone pairs of electrons have strong coordination capability with single metal atoms. Therefore, coordination design strategy that constructs coordination atoms as anchoring sites on the surface of carbon substrates is another important strategy to stabilize SACs from aggregation. In particular, the pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen in nitrogen-doped carbon materials can offer abundant coordination sites to anchor various metal atoms [96,104]. These coordination N on carbon is introduced by pyrolysis under NH3 atmosphere or by pyrolysis under Ar atmosphere with nitrogen sources such as melamine [105], polymers containing N species [106], and g-C3N4 templates [107,108]. Niu et al. used glucose and dicyandiamide as the templates of nitrogen-doped graphene (NG), and NiCl2·6H2O salt as the precursor of single Ni atoms [107]. After mixing, the precursor was annealed under Ar atmosphere, and SA-Ni@NG with a Ni-N4 structure was obtained. Isolated Ni atoms were also confined into the NG substrate with the assistance of sacrificed g-C3N4 templates. The Ni-N4 sites act as polysulfide traps by forming strong S x 2--Ni-N bonding, accelerating the kinetic conversion of LiPS during the charge/discharge process. The O-containing functional groups on graphene oxide (GO) can provide abundant sites to disperse mononuclear metal complexes. Wan et al. prepared SA-Co@NG with CoNC catalytic centers as the sulfur host of Li-S batteries [109]. Monodisperse Co atoms were embedded in the NG framework with the help of GO precursors. CoCl2•6H2O aqueous solution was added into the GO suspension under vigorous sonication. The precursor was freeze-dried and heat treated under Ar/NH3 to obtain SA-Co@NG. Taking advantage of strong S-Co interaction, Dou et al. designed a “top-down” pyrolysis strategy to fabricate SA-Co@hollow carbon sphere (HC)@S as the cathode for Na-S batteries (Fig. 5b) [110]. Initially, CoCl2 solution was immersed into the hollow carbon spheres, and was reduced to Co nanoparticles that uniformly decorated on the carbon shells (Co@HC) by thermal treatment. Through further thermal treatment, melted S was loaded into Co@HC. When the temperature was up to 300 °C, sulfur molecules with strong interaction with Co nanoparticles began diffusing and served as traction for atomic Co migration onto carbon shells, forming uniformly dispersed SA-Co. Reasonable combination of spatial confinement strategy and coordination design strategy is important to achieve high-loading SACs (Fig. 5c). Recently, Wan et al. developed a cascade anchoring strategy to prepare SA-Co@nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) with Co loading as high as 12.1 wt% for ORR catalysis [105]. Systematic investigation revealed that the chelation of mononuclear metal ions, physical isolation of chelate complex on oxygen-rich carbon substrate, and pyrolysis to form Co-N x sites by melamine are essential to achieving high-loading SACs. When such a high catalyst loading is achieved on the sulfur host, it can be expected that the catalytic effect will be greatly improved. In addition to the pyrolysis method (the above mentioned strategies are listed in Fig. 5c), other methods such as atomic layer deposition (ALD) [111], high-energy ball milling [112], and microwave-assisted synthesis [113], have been reported to fabricate SAC@carbon materials. However, owing to high production cost and complicated process, the practicability cannot be compared with the pyrolysis method. 3.2 Characterization of SACs Since SACs are at atomic scale, characterization methods for nanoscale catalysts are not sufficient to characterize SACs because of relatively low resolution. Advanced ex-situ and in-situ characterization methods should be used (Fig. 6 ). The ex-situ structural characterization can verify the existence of single atoms on a substrate and determine the spatial distribution, while the in-situ characterization can provide dynamic changes of both reactants and SACs during electrochemical process, which is important for analyzing the catalytic mechanism. 3.2.1 Ex-situ characterization of SACs The information probed by ex-situ characterization methods for SACs is listed in Table 1 . Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) are usually used to reveal the existence and distribution of SACs on a substrate. AC-HAADF-STEM images are formed by collecting high-angle and incoherently scattered electrons (Rutherford scattered electrons) by an annular dark-field detector in the STEM. With sensitive to variations in the atomic number of atoms in the sample, AC-HAADF-STEM with sub Å resolution can directly identify single atoms on a carbon substrate [114]. From AC-HAADF-STEM image of SA-Co@NG (Fig. 7 a), individual single atoms (seen as bright spots) are randomly dispersed on the nitrogen-doped graphene [109]. EDS coupling with electron microscopy can obtain elemental maps with Å resolution [115,116]. From EDS element mappings of SA-Fe/NC (Fig. 7b), almost all Fe atoms are highly dispersed in the nitrogen-doped carbon layer [117]. Synchrotron-radiated X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) are two powerful characterization methods to reveal the coordination environment and electronic state of SACs. XPS is a surface-sensitive spectroscopic technique based on the photoelectric effect. When a material is irradiated with a beam of X-ray (Al K α with an energy of 1486.6 eV), photoelectrons are subsequently ejected from atoms in the near surface (less than 10 nm) [118,119]. By measuring the kinetic energy of photoelectrons, the XPS spectra containing the elemental composition, concentration and chemical environment of the material surface can be obtained. XPS can obtain partial information of the coordination structure of SACs by detecting coordination atoms. As shown in Fig. 7(c), only pyridinic N peak of SA-Co@NG up-shifts by ~ 0.4 eV with respect to its position in NG, implying that Co atoms in SA-Co@NG were primarily bond to pyridinic N [109]. XAS based on synchrotron radiation collects the absorption spectrum of the target element from its near absorption edge (K, L, M) to the certain energy range, and measures the X-ray absorption coefficient as a function of energy [120]. When the spectral region is extended to 30–50 or 50–1000 eV, it is called X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy, respectively [121]. With high resolution and signal-to-noise ratio, XAS can directly obtain the coordination structure and oxidation state of single metal atoms. Fourier transform (FT) of the EXAFS signal as a function of wavenumber is related to the radial distribution of coordination atoms in real space [114]. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the FT-EXAFS spectra of SA-Co@NG showed only one strong shell (1.33 Å), which is considered as Co-N bond. The absence of Co-Co bonds reveals that no clusters or nanoparticles are formed. As an alternative method, the wavelet transform (WT) has been proposed to replace the infinitely expanded periodic oscillations in FT with located wavelets [122]. As shown in Fig. 7(e), SA-Co@NG shows only one WT maximum at 4.6 Å−1, which can be assigned to Co-N bond. Fig. 7(f) is the XANES spectra of SA-Co@NG and reference samples. The pre-edge peak (line A) is a fingerprint of the Co-N4 square-planar structure, while the near-edge absorption energy (line B) of SA-Co@NG is between Co3O4 and Co foil, indicating that Co atoms are positively charged. To effectively characterize the content of single atoms on a substrate, XPS and the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) are often used. ICP-OES produces excited ions and atoms that emit a detectable amount of light at characteristic wavelengths and measures the light intensity with proportional to the concentration [123]. ICP-OES with functions of simultaneous analysis of multiple elements, high sensitivity and stability can acquire accurate mass loading of SACs. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has relatively low accuracy and sensitivity, so it is seldom used in the case of SACs with a low mass ratio in the sample. 3.2.2 In-situ characterization of sulfur electrodes In-situ characterization techniques such as in-situ XRD, in-situ XAS, and in-situ Raman, are emerging as advanced methods to obtain real-time information of reaction kinetic processes. By performing the “screening” of the structural evolution of both sulfur species and SACs during the electrochemical process, the catalytic effect and mechanism of SACs for sulfur electrodes can be well studied. Fig. 8 (a) shows in-situ XRD patterns of the SA-Co@HC@S cathode in a Na-S battery [110]. The second discharge process does not show any trace of Na2S2, and the diffraction peak intensity of Na2S4 obviously decreases. It indicates that SA-Co can quickly catalyze the reduction from Na2S4 to Na2S, and effectively reduce the dissolution of Na2S4 during cycling. In-situ XANES spectroscopy can detect the oxidation state of SACs during the electrochemical process and further speculate the interaction between SACs and sulfur species. As shown in Fig. 8(b), at time t 1 (corresponding to a charging state), the Fe K-edge shiftes to a lower energy from the initial state, indicating a reduced valence state of Fe [124]. This shift is presumably caused by the interaction between SA-Fe and S atom in Li2S. At time t 2, the Fe K-edge shifts back to the initial energy, indicating the polysulfide chain is detached from SA-Fe. Wan et al. performed in-situ XANES measurements to judge the catalytic effect of SA-Co@NG on LiPS conversion [109]. The concentration change of intermediates can be judged by intensity change of each peak (Fig. 8c). A clear rise of peak D is observed at the beginning of discharge for E>2.1 V, indicating the generation of Li2S at the early stage of discharge. This early formation of Li2S demonstrates the improved electrochemical kinetics from soluble LiPS to insoluble Li2S by SA-Co. Fig. 8(d) shows the voltage profile of a Li-S battery with a SA-Fe@NG-modified separator and the Raman signals at each collection point (A1-A9) [125]. Comparing the Raman signals of the SA-Fe@NG-modified separator with that of a commercial polypropylene separator, the promoted conversion kinetics of polysulfides and the complete sulfur conversion are achieved by catalysis of SA-Fe@NG. Combining advanced ex/in-situ characterization techniques with theoretical calculation is important for verifying the existence of SACs, determining the local coordination environment, and most importantly, understanding the catalytic mechanism of SACs. Deep understanding of the catalytic mechanism of SACs at atomic and molecular level can inspire to prepare SACs with better performance. 3.3 Enhanced electrochemical performance by SACs A variety of SAC (mainly SA-Fe, Co, and Ni)/carbon materials have been developed and used for cathodes, separators, and electrolytes in Li/Na-S batteries. By accelerating the conversion of sulfur species, SACs can effectively reduce the polarization and suppress the shuttle effect, and further improve rate and cycling performance. SAC/carbon materials as a sulfur host have been investigated to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Lee and co-workers used SA-Fe@spherical mesoporous carbon (SA-Fe@S-MCF) as the sulfur host. The uniform distribution of FeNC sites (only 0.33 wt% of Fe) has high electrocatalytic effect for sulfur conversion [103]. CV profiles of the Li-S batteries were measured (Fig. 9 a). The first cathodic peak corresponds to the reduction of sulfur to LiPS, while the second cathodic peak reflects further reduction of LiPS to Li2S. Two anodic peaks correspond to the reverse process of reduction. The positive shift in the cathodic peaks, negative shift in the anodic peaks, and increased current reflected the promoted redox kinetics by SA-Fe. In addition, the SA-Fe decorated sulfur cathode exhibites a smaller Tafel slope and lower overpotential during the discharging process (Fig. 9b), which indicate the improved kinetics of LiPS reduction. Beneficial with the promoted redox kinetics of LiPS by FeNC sites, the SA-Fe@S-MCF@S cathode retained 64% of the capacity even at 5C, and resulted in outstanding cycling performance with 5.2 mg cm−2 of sulfur loading. To verify the catalytic role of SA-Fe, Liu et al. prepared nanocage-like nitrogen-rich MOF-derived carbon decorated with SA-Fe (SA-Fe@NC) as the sulfur host [126]. The smaller degree of polarization can be observed at the charge/discharge plateaus owing to the catalytic effect for LiPS (Fig. 9c). As shown in Fig. 9(d), the SA-Fe@NC@S electrode shows a lower overpotential of the potential hill at the first charge plateau compared with NC@S electrode, revealing that the conversion of insoluble Li2S to soluble LiPS are easier under the catalytic effect of SA-Fe. Even at a high rate of 4C, the capacity retention of the SA-Fe@NC@S electrode is maintained 70% over 500 cycles (Fig. 9e). The above results suggest that SA-Fe as electrocatalyst can effectively solve the problem of slow kinetics of sulfur electrode, improve the rate and cycling performance. In addition to SA-Fe, SA-Co was also found to show catalytic effect of polysulfide conversion. Due to the large Na+ radius, the transport kinetics of Na+ is slower than Li+. Therefore, for Na-S batteries, the catalytic effect is more obvious. The atomic cobalt-decorated hollow carbon nanospheres (SA-Co@HC) synthesized by Zhang et al. have obviously enhanced the sulfur reactivity and electrocatalytically reduced polysulfides to the final product, Na2S [110]. SA-Co with surface sulfurization can effectively alleviate the NaPS dissolution based on polar-polar interactions, and further promote the reduction of NaPS (Fig. 10 ). Therefore, SA-Co in sulfur cathode plays a critical role in achieving sustainable cycling stability and high reversible capacity. The constructed sulfur cathode delivered an initial reversible capacity of 1081 mAh/g at 100 mA g−1, retaining excellent reversible capacity of 508 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles. Moreover, SA-Co@HC@S cathode exhibited a reversible capability of 220 mA h g−1 at 5 A/g, among the best in the field of room-temperature Na-S batteries. The catalytic effect of SAC/carbon materials used in separators has also been well investigated. In separators, a conductive carbon network not only acts as a physical barrier to block polysulfides but also as an “additional current collector” to improve the sulfur utilization. SACs on the carbon substrate can effectively serve as electrocatalyst to boost the reversible reaction of LiPS (Fig. 11 ). Xie et al. prepared a SA-Fe@NG-modified separator to catalyze polysulfide conversion, resulting in the reduced voltage gap and much improved cycle life [125]. The Li-S battery showed long-term cycling performance that retained 83.7% capacity (892 mAh/g) after 750 cycles at 0.5C, at 4.5 mg cm−2 of sulfur loading. Guo et al. designed a freestanding and flexible multifunctional interlayer by assembling the 2D ultrathin SA-Co@NC and carbon nanotube-cellulose nanofiber (CNT-CNF) hybrid network to enhance the confinement and redox reaction of polysulfides [127]. Li-S batteries with the SA-Co@NC modified interlayer delivered an ultralow capacity decay of 0.058% per cycle over 700 cycles at 2C. The electrocatalytic role of SA-Ni was investigated by Niu et al. [107]. SA-Ni@NG with Ni-N4 sites was used to modify the separator of Li-S batteries. By forming strong interactions with LiPS, the undesirable shuttle effect was suppressed, and the kinetic conversion of LiPS was accelerated by Ni-N4 sites. Therefore, the Li-S battery with the SA-Ni@NG-modified separator exhibited excellent rate performance and stable cycling life over 500 cycles with only 0.06% capacity decay per cycle. SACs as an electrolyte additive was investigated by Yang et al. to promote the LiPS conversion and Li2S nucleation [128]. Single Co atoms are uniformly dispersed in cobalt hexadecachlorophthalocyanine (CoPcCl) molecules. Unlike SAC/carbon materials as the sulfur host, soluble SACs cannot be covered by the solid discharge/charge products that cause failures of the catalyst. Moreover, soluble SACs can bond with LiPS in the electrolyte and transfer to the conductive framework of cathode to perform fast conversion. During CV tests of the symmetric cells with Li2S6 added into the electrolyte, standard electrolyte (STD)-CoPcCl displays the highest current response (Fig. 12 a), indicating that CoPcCl significantly promotes the reaction kinetics of the LiPS conversion. Potentiostatic discharge experiments show that a higher precipitation capacity achieved by CoPcCl (Fig. 12b, c), which means that the presence of CoPcCl promotes LiPS reduction and Li2S nucleation, thus enhances the sulfur utilization. Therefore, Li-S batteries with CoPcCl as the electrolyte additive exhibits improved long-term cycling and rate performance (Fig. 12d, e). SACs used in cathodes and separators were studied more than in electrolyte. Compared with SACs as electrolyte additives, SACs embedded in the carbon substrate used in cathode/separators cannot affect the electrolyte nature or electrolyte/anode interphase. It is relative easier to achieve high-loading SACs due to the high specific area of carbon substrate. The key point is to stabilize SACs on the substrate against migration and aggregation during preparation and electrochemical operation. In addition, SAC@carbon material is appropriate to be the model catalyst to understand the catalytic mechanism. However, SACs are possible to be covered by the solid sulfides that cause failures of the catalyst, or detach from the carbon skeleton to form large aggregation during the long-term cycling. In contrast, SACs as electrolyte additives are often organometallic molecules. The specific molecular structure cannot lead to aggregation of single metal atoms, and most organometallic molecules are easily available with low production cost. The soluble SACs cannot be covered by the solid discharge/charge products as well. However, the chemical stability of soluble SACs in the electrolyte under an applied electric field and compatibility with lithium anode should be thoroughly investigated. It is also hard to achieve high SACs loading due to the limited solubility in the electrolyte. Up to now, only a few kinds of SACs (SA-Fe, Co, Ni, V) as a part of cathode, modified separator or electrolyte have been reported for Li/Na-S batteries. The electrochemical performances of Li/Na-S batteries with SACs are shown in Table 2 . Most of SACs have been used in Li-S batteries, and the cycling and rate performance are improved obviously. However, studies on coexistant condition of both high sulfur loading and low E/S ratio are scant, which can be explored by further optimizing the structure and content of SACs to obtain higher catalytic efficiency. 4 Summary and perspective We have summerized the current progress on SACs in sulfur electrodes from aspects of synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical performance. For synthesis, researchers have fabricated various SAC/carbon materials for sulfur electrodes by pyrolysis method. Reasonable combination of spatial confinement strategy and coordination design strategy is important to achieve large-scale preparation of SACs. For characterization, combining ex/in-situ characterization with theoretical calculationa is important for verifying the existence of SAC, determining the local coordination environment, and most importantly, understanding the catalytic mechanism of SACs. For electrochemical performance, ultra-fast redox kinetics of sulfur species provided by SA-Fe, Co, and Ni result in improved rate and cycling performance. At present, research on SACs applying in metal-sulfur batteries is still in infancy and immature. Many challenges need to be solved and optimized in order to achieve the high-performance sulfur electrodes. As shown in Fig. 13 , four aspects of synthesis, application, characterization, and electrochemical performance (middle layer) around SACs for sulfur electrodes (core) need to be improved. The specific issues (outer layer) are discussed as follows. (1) Use facile synthesis strategies and achieve large-scale preparation of SACs. As mentioned above, pervious works has almost used only the pyrolysis method to prepare SAC/carbon materials for sulfur electrodes. To prevent the aggregation of single atoms, a small amount of SAC precursor is usually added, resulting in a low content of SACs (<2 wt%) within the carbon material. The content of SACs is closely related to the catalytic efficiency, and the improved catalytic efficiency is beneficial to load more sulfur on the cathode. It needs to improve the diversity of synthesis strategies, including spatial confinement strategy and coordination design strategy as mentioned above to achieve high-loading SAC synthesis (>10 wt% of mass ratio). Other methods such as ALD, electrochemical and photochemical methods, should be further developed to prepare high-quality SACs with simplified production process. Practically, it needs to select low-cost and scalable synthesis methods to promote the practical use of SACs in metal-sulfur batteries. In addition, only SA-Fe, Co, Ni, and V have been applied in sulfur electrodes so far. To broaden the application of SACs in metal-sulfur batteries, more types of SACs must be prepared. It is beneficial to systematically study the catalytic effect of different SACs and obtain general knowledge. (2) Broaden the applications of SACs. Current research shows that SACs used in the cathode, separator/interlayer and electrolyte in Li/Na-S batteries exhibit outstanding catalytic effects to accelerate the redox of sulfur species. It is expected that the development of SACs can be expanded to other metal-sulfur (K-S, Mg-S, Ca-S, Al-S) batteries due to the similar sulfur cathode chemistry. When try to fully understand the mechanism of other metal-sulfur batteries, SACs can play an important role in accelerating the redox reaction of sulfur cathode as they work in Li/Na-S batteries, and potentially improve the electrochemical performance. For Mg-S, Ca-S and Al-S batteries, the relatively high charge density of Mg2+, Ca2+ and Al3+ than Li+ hampers their transport in crystal lattice and deteriorates the reaction kinetics of sulfur cathode, while SACs have huge potential to enhance the sluggish kinetics of these battery systems. SACs used in different battery compositions (cathode, separator/interlayer, electrolyte) need to be further explored, in order to determine the various parameters of SACs that affect catalytic activity and entire battery system. Simultaneously, the possible negative effects by SACs need to be considered, including possible decomposition of electrolytes, negative effects on anode (instability of SEI, consumption of active materials, etc.), and acceleration of self-discharge, which is an important factor for commercial use of batteries. (3) Identify the catalytic mechanism of SACs by advanced ex/in-situ characterization and theoretical calculation techniques is the focus of the next phase of research. So far, the local coordination environment of “SAC-reactant”, the number of catalytic sites of a single atom, and the chemical state during charge/discharge process, etc. are not definitely understood. These factors introduce huge uncertainties to the catalytic mechanism. It is not clear whether SACs will be deactivated in long-term cycling, which is related to their practical application. Therefore, advanced calculation and characterization techniques, such as spectrum fitting, energy optimization, and in-situ detection, are needed to address these issues, to control the entire electrochemical process precisely. (4) Strictly control the test conditions for electrochemical performance. As mentioned before, SACs can enhance the redox kinetics of sulfur electrodes to improve the rate capability and cycling performance. On one hand, it should pay more attention to long cycle and high rate test conditions. On the other hand, high areal sulfur loading and low electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio are keys when considering practical metal-sulfur batteries. The performance of metal-sulfur batteries will be further improved by optimizing the coordination structure and content of SACs to obtain more remarkable catalytic effect. Based on these, the practical use of SACs to achieve excellent electrochemical performance of metal-sulfur batteries needs more exploration in the future. Ru Xiao received her B.S. (2019) in Materials Processing and Control from Northeastern University in China. She is currently a graduate student at the Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her research is focused on the design and application of novel nano-carbon materials and carbon-based composite materials for high-energy-density lithium-sulfur batteries. Zhenhua Sun is currently a professor at Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees in inorganic chemistry from Jilin University in 2001 and 2006, respectively. Then he was a Postdoctoral Research Fellow in the Chinese University of Hong Kong from 2007 to 2009. His current research interests mainly focused on the synthesis and application of nano-carbon materials and carbon-based composite materials for electrochemical energy storage. He has published more than 80 papers in peer-reviewing journals including Nature Communications, Advanced Materials, etc. with 5200 citations (H-index 33). Hui-Ming Cheng is Professor and Director of both Advanced Carbon Research Division of Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science, Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and the Low-Dimensional Material and Device Laboratory of the Tsinghua-Berkeley Shenzhen Institute, Tsinghua University. His research activities focus on carbon nanotubes, graphene, other 2D materials, energy storage materials, photocatalytic semiconducting materials, and bulk carbon materials. He is recognized as a Highly Cited Researcher in both materials science and chemistry fields by Thomson Reuters. He is the founding Editor-in-Chief of Energy Storage Materials and the Associate Editor of Science China Materials. Feng Li is a professor of the Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences (IMR, CAS). He received his Ph.D. in materials science at IMR, CAS in 2001 supervised by Prof. Hui-Ming Cheng. He mainly works on the novel carbon materials and energy materials. He has published more 300 papers on peer-reviewed journals, such as Nature Energy, Energy Storage Materials, Adv Mater, J Energy Chem, etc. with more 30000 citations and H-index about 80. He obtained the award of National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars by National Foundation of Science China, and Highly Cited Researcher by Clarivate Analytics.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-sulfur batteries are recognized as a promising candidate for next generation electrochemical energy storage systems owing to their high theoretical energy density, low cost and environmental friendliness. However, sluggish redox kinetics of sulfur species and the shuttle effect lead to large polarization and severe capacity decay. Numerous approaches from physical barrier, chemical adsorption strategies to electrocatalysts have been tried to solve these issues and pushed the rate and cycle performance of sulfur electrodes to higher levels. Most recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) with high catalytic efficiency have been introduced into metal-sulfur systems to achieve fast redox kinetics of sulfur conversion. In this review, we systematically summarize the current progress on SACs for sulfur electrodes from aspects of synthesis, characterization and electrochemical performance. Challenges and potential solutions for designing SACs for high-performance sulfur electrodes are discussed.
